lexicon_requests.reason: Opening refuge formula - semantic range of חסה and theological significance of taking refuge in YHWH
Ketiv/qere textual variant - need to understand נוד root and why feminine singular imperative is puzzling
Rare term from שׁית root - crux of v.3, could be architectural/cosmic/metaphorical foundations
Unusual anthropomorphism for divine vision - why 'eyelids' specifically rather than just 'eyes'?
Unusual prefix בְּמוֹ - need to understand this rare construction and how it differs from simple בְּ
Testing/examination vocabulary - metallurgical or judicial connotations? Central to psalm's theology
Violence/injustice - semantic range and why 'lover of violence' is emphasized
Snares/traps in judgment context - why hunting imagery combined with theophanic fire/sulfur?
Sulfur with Sodom allusion - need intertextual connections and theological freight
Scorching wind - rare term, exact meaning unclear, part of judgment catalog
Cup/portion metaphor - inheritance imagery in judgment context, theological significance
Plural form - abstract intensity ('righteousness') or concrete plurality ('righteous deeds')? Theological implications

concordance_requests.purpose: Track refuge formula across Psalter - how psalmists use this opening declaration
Investigate ketiv variant - is plural imperative 'flee to your mountains' attested elsewhere?
Find all occurrences of this rare 'foundations' term to determine meaning
Track divine 'eyelids' anthropomorphism - is this imagery unique or formulaic?
Search for this rhetorical question pattern about righteous action/inaction
Track 'in his holy temple' formula - cultic or heavenly temple?
Divine throne in heaven imagery across Scripture
Behold God's face language - relation to Exod 33:20 prohibition
Upright of heart as moral category in Psalter

Darkness as moral/literal concealment - wicked operating hidden | Vehicle: darkness | Related terms: dark, gloom, shadow, shadows
Foundations being destroyed - architectural/cosmic collapse metaphor | Vehicle: foundations | Related terms: foundation, base
Eyelids examining - intensified divine vision anthropomorphism | Vehicle: eyelids | Related terms: eyelid
Testing as refining - metallurgical examination metaphor | Vehicle: test | Related terms: tests, testing, examine, examines, examining
Rain as judgment inversion - life-giving inverted to death-dealing | Vehicle: rain | Related terms: rains, raining, pour, pours, pouring
Snares in judgment - hunting trap imagery | Vehicle: snares | Related terms: snare, trap, traps, net, nets
Fire and sulfur - Sodom theophanic judgment allusion | Vehicle: sulfur | Related terms: brimstone
Cup as allotted destiny - inheritance/portion metaphor | Vehicle: cup | Related terms: cups, chalice

commentary_requests.reason: Opening refuge declaration with divine name emphasis - how do commentators frame the psalmist's confidence and the dialogical structure that follows?
Ketiv/qere variant and counsel to flee - traditional interpretation of who is speaking and why feminine singular imperative
Detailed archery imagery in darkness - how commentators understand the immediacy of threat and moral/literal darkness
Central crux about foundations being destroyed - classical exegesis of what 'foundations' means (temple/cosmos/social order/Torah)
Unanswered rhetorical question 'what can the righteous do' - how commentators handle this syntactic and theological puzzle
Double location formula (temple/heaven throne) - traditional understanding of simultaneity vs. identification
Eyes and eyelids anthropomorphism - how commentators explain the unusual specificity of divine vision
God testing both righteous and wicked - traditional interpretation of whether this is positive (refining) or threatening
God's soul/nephesh hating - how commentators handle this anthropomorphic language of divine emotion
Catalog of judgment elements (snares, fire, sulfur, wind) - classical understanding of the accumulation and Sodom allusion
Tripartite conclusion about God's righteousness - how commentators integrate character, action, and promise
Upright beholding God's face - traditional resolution of tension with Exod 33:20 prohibition (cultic/eschatological/metaphorical?)

macro_questions: What is the textual issue in v. 1b with the ketiv נודו versus qere נוּדִי? Does the feminine singular imperative address נֶפֶשׁ (soul) as feminine, or is there a scribal issue? How does this affect translation and interpretation?

What are the 'foundations' (הַשָּׁתוֹת) in v. 3? Is this architectural (temple/city), cosmic (earth's foundations), social (justice system), or moral (ethical order)? How is this root used elsewhere in the Hebrew Bible, and what would 'destroyed foundations' signify to ancient Israelites?

How does the dual location in v. 4—'temple' (הֵיכַל) and 'throne in heaven'—relate to temple theology and divine presence? Does this reflect simultaneous immanence/transcendence, or is 'heavenly throne' a description of the earthly temple as microcosm of heaven? Compare ancient Near Eastern temple cosmology.

The imagery in v. 6 (fire, sulfur, scorching wind) clearly echoes Sodom and Gomorrah (Gen 19:24). How does this intertextual connection function rhetorically? Does the 'raining down' verb (מטר) deliberately invert blessing to curse? Are there other biblical or ancient Near Eastern parallels to divine judgment as anti-rain?

What is the significance of 'beholding His face' (יֶחֱזוּ פָנֵימוֹ) in v. 7b given the tension with Exod 33:20 ('no one can see My face and live')? Is this cultic (seeing God in temple worship), eschatological (future beatific vision), or metaphorical (experiencing divine favor)? How do other Psalms use 'seeing God's face' language?

The verb בחן (test/examine) in vv. 4-5 suggests metallurgical refining. How does this testing language relate to wisdom literature (Job, Proverbs) and to other Psalms? Is YHWH's testing of the righteous (v. 5a) positive (purification) or neutral (examination)? What is being tested?

How does the 'refuge' language (חָסִיתִי, v. 1a) connect to temple asylum practices in ancient Israel? Are there legal/cultic dimensions to 'taking refuge in YHWH'? Compare other Psalms using this root (חסה) and consider whether this psalm reflects an actual asylum seeker at the temple being counseled to flee.

The contrast between the wicked shooting 'from darkness' (בְּמוֹ־אֹפֶל, v. 2) and God's comprehensive vision (v. 4) creates an epistemological theme. How does darkness/light function theologically in Psalms and wisdom literature? Is darkness moral (ignorance of divine observation), epistemological (inability to see), or both?

The phrase 'upright in heart' (יִשְׁרֵי־לֵב, v. 2) and 'upright' (יָשָׁר, v. 7) frames the description of the righteous. How does יָשָׁר relate to צַדִּיק (righteous)? Are these synonyms, or do they emphasize different aspects of moral character (straightness/integrity vs. righteousness)?

How does Psalm 11's structure and themes relate to other 'trust' psalms (e.g., Psalms 4, 16, 23, 27, 62)? Are there common features (declaration of trust, description of threat, affirmation of divine protection)? Does Psalm 11's emphasis on divine examination and judgment distinguish it from other trust psalms?
micro_questions: What accounts for the ketiv/qere variant נודו/נוּדִי in v.1, and does the feminine singular imperative suggest נֶפֶשׁ (soul) as grammatical addressee?
What exactly are 'the foundations' (הַשָּׁתוֹת) in v.3—architectural, cosmic, social, or moral—and how does this rare term function elsewhere in the Hebrew Bible?
Why does v.4 use the specific body-part 'eyelids' (עַפְעַפָּיו) rather than just 'eyes'—what does this unusual anthropomorphism contribute?
How should we understand God's 'testing' (בחן) of the righteous in v.5—is this positive (refining), neutral (examination), or threatening (trial)?
What is the function of the unusual prefix בְּמוֹ in 'בְּמוֹ־אֹפֶל' (v.2), and how does it differ from simple בְּ?
Why does v.6 combine hunting imagery (snares/פַּחִים) with theophanic judgment imagery (fire, sulfur, scorching wind)?
How does the psalm's promise that 'the upright shall behold His face' (v.7) relate to the prohibition in Exod 33:20 that no one can see God's face and live?
Is the plural צְדָקוֹת in v.7 abstract intensity ('righteousness') or concrete plurality ('righteous deeds'), and what theological difference does this make?
Why does the psalm leave the central rhetorical question of v.3 ('what can the righteous do?') syntactically unanswered?
What is the relationship between the 'holy temple' and 'throne in heaven' in v.4—simultaneity, identification, or poetic parallelism?
